coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of asymmetric bilayer solid-state electrolyte with boosted ion transport enabled by charge-rich space charge layer for ‐20~70°C lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Jin
Cai, Yingjun
Cui, Yingyue
Wu, Hui
Da, Haoran
Yang, Yijun
Zhang, Haitao
Zhang, Suojiang
coredata.dc:description: Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO), a typical oxidizing ceramic solid electrolyte of excellent lithium-ion conductivity, is considered as a promising candidate for next-generation high-energy-density solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs). However, great challenges, such as the unexpected growth of lithium dendrites and the excessive resistance of electrolyte/electrode interface, need to be well addressed through their commercialization. Here, a local conjugated polymer solid-state electrolytes nanolayer was formed onto ceramic oxide particles via selective adsorption through an in-situ polymerization process. Li solid NMR spectra and TEM (ex-situ and in-situ) characterizations suggest that optimized layer provided effective pathways for Li+ conduction between SSEs and ceramic oxide. Consequently, this composite electrolyte possesses a high ionic conductivity of 0.69 mS cm−1 at 25 °C. Lithium symmetrical batteries exhibit a reduced charge voltage polarization and the critical current density could be increased up to 2.4 mA cm−2. Moreover, lithium metal batteries based on CPE show an excellent cycle stability over a broad temperature range from −20 to 70 °C, and super-long cycling performance (> 600 cycles) at 0.5 C under 0 °C. This new strategy creates a new route to resolve the LLZTO/electrode interface issue by constructing rich-large space charge layer and promoting Li+ conduction, it will be helpful for the commercialization and application of wide-temperatures SSLMBs.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Solid-state electrolytes
Interface
Oxidizing ceramic
Lithium-ion transport
Space charge layer

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Schematic illustration shows the functional effect of GF and LLZTO on Li-metal batteries: 1) 3D fiber-network and selective adsorption; 2) pathways for Li+ conduction between SSEs and ceramic oxide, and effective suppression Li dendrites on lithium anode. (b) Complex structure of the LLZTO (001) surface interacted with TPGDA in SSEs and calculated CDD at the heterointerface of LLZTO/SSEs. Yellow and blue isosurface represent electron accumulation and depletion regions, respectively. (c) 7Li solid-state NMR spectra of LLZTO, SSEs, and LLZTO@SSEs.

(a) X-ray computed tomography of CPE-10% LLZTO. SEM and inset digital images of CPE −10% LLZTO membranes from the disassembled batteries with different sides (b) near cathode. (c) near anode. (d-e) TEM images (f) EDS mapping and (g) the XPS spectra of LLZTO@SSEs ceramic oxide.

(a) Temperature dependence of ionic conductivity of CPE-0% LLZTO and CPE-10% LLZTO films. (b) Comparison of FTIR spectra of TPGDA, VEImNTF2 and CPE-10%LLZTO. (c) LSV curves with a scan rate of 1 mV s – 1. (d) Chronoamperometry profile of Li/CPE/Li battery; inset: the impedance responses of the cell under initial/steady-state conditions (e) force–distance curves of CPE-10% LLZTO. (f) Radar plot that compares the performance of CPE-0% LLZTO and CPE-10% LLZTO.

(a) Rate performance test of the Li/CPE-10% LLZTO /Li cell to determine its critical current density with a stripping/plating period of 5 min (b) Long-term galvanostatic cycling profile of the Li/ CPEs /Li cell measured at RT. SEM images of cycled Li (c) without and with (d-e) 10 wt% LLZTO additives in Li||Li symmetric cells.
(a) XPS spectra of cycled Li metal with CPE-0% LLZTO and CPE-10% LLZTO, C 1 s, P 2p, and F 1 s (b) Digital images and diagram of in situ TEM test. (c) Time-lapse in-situ TEM images during lithiation.

Cycling performance of CPEs in solid-state Li/LFP cells. (a) rate performances from 0.2 C to 2.0 C and long cycling performances at 0.5 C at 25 ℃. (b) Charge/discharge voltage profiles at different temperatures at 0.5 C with CPE-10% LLZTO. (c) Long cycling performances at 0.5 C at 0 ℃ with CPE-10% LLZTO. (d) Discharge capacity and coulombic efficiency of a Li/ CPE-10% LLZTO /LFP battery at −20 °C and −10 °C under different current rates with CPE-10% LLZTO. TEM images of cycled LFP particles exposed with (e-f) CPE-0% LLZTO and CPE-10% LLZTO electrolytes. (g) Photographs of lightened red LED device under flatting conditions.

head.ce:title: Fabrication of asymmetric bilayer solid-state electrolyte with boosted ion transport enabled by charge-rich space charge layer for ‐20~70°C lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO), a typical oxidizing ceramic solid electrolyte of excellent lithium-ion conductivity, is considered as a promising candidate for next-generation high-energy-density solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs). However, great challenges, such as the unexpected growth of lithium dendrites and the excessive resistance of electrolyte/electrode interface, need to be well addressed through their commercialization. Here, a local conjugated polymer solid-state electrolytes nanolayer was formed onto ceramic oxide particles via selective adsorption through an in-situ polymerization process. Li solid NMR spectra and TEM (ex-situ and in-situ) characterizations suggest that optimized layer provided effective pathways for Li+ conduction between SSEs and ceramic oxide. Consequently, this composite electrolyte possesses a high ionic conductivity of 0.69 mS cm−1 at 25 °C. Lithium symmetrical batteries exhibit a reduced charge voltage polarization and the critical current density could be increased up to 2.4 mA cm−2. Moreover, lithium metal batteries based on CPE show an excellent cycle stability over a broad temperature range from −20 to 70 °C, and super-long cycling performance (> 600 cycles) at 0.5 C under 0 °C. This new strategy creates a new route to resolve the LLZTO/electrode interface issue by constructing rich-large space charge layer and promoting Li+ conduction, it will be helpful for the commercialization and application of wide-temperatures SSLMBs.

An asymmetric bilayer solid-stated electrolyte was synthesized via a simple selective adsorption and in-situ thermal polymerization process. Such a configuration can create a new route to resolve the LLZTO/electrode interface issue by constructing rich-large space charge layer and promote Li+ conduction. Assembled LiFePO4/Li battery could deliver excellent cycling performance at −20 – 70 ℃.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical energy storage devices are critical for the realization of decarbonization goal [1–4]. Lithium-ion batteries are dominating the consumer electronics market, such as electric vehicles, due to their ultrahigh energy density [5–9]. However, there are corrosiveness and thermal instability in conventional liquid electrolytes [10,11]. Therefore, SSEs are a reliable alternatives for liquid electrolytes to ensure the security of batteries [12,13]. Generally, common solid electrolytes are classified into solid inorganic electrolytes (SIEs), solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), and composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) [14–16]. Among them, SIEs such as Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) and Li1.5Al0.5Ti1.5(PO4)3 (LATP) exhibit superior ionic conductivity and lithium-ion transference number, these features can guard the wide operating temperature [17–21]. However, SIEs are limited to the application by the large electrolyte/electrode interface impedance and the narrow electrochemical window [22,23]. SPEs are composed of polymer matrix and Li salts, therefore, they are more flexible, easier to process, and exhibit reduced resistance to electrodes [24–26]. Due to the strong solubility of lithium salts, ether polymers such as poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO) with soft chains and low cost, are considered as an excellent electrolyte matrix [27–29]. However, this type of SPEs own lower ionic conductivity and mechanical properties at room temperature, resulting into unexpected penetration by Li dendrites [26,30]. As a combination of SIEs and SPEs, CPEs inherit the advantages of inorganic and polymer electrolytes, which are considered as the effective competitors of current high-performance SSLMBs [18,31–34].

Previous literatures suggest that the presence a small number of ceramic oxides can reduce crystallization and improve the ionic conductivity of CPE [27]. Note that limited number of ceramic particles cannot effectively improve the mechanics of CPE to suppress lithium dendrites. Once ceramics are used as the main body, the high mechanical strength of CPE can be regarded as a mechanical barrier to inhibit lithium dendrite [35]. However, these CPEs may seriously depress the overall conductivity due to the enhanced electrolyte/electrode interface resistance. Many strategies have been proposed to design multilayer SSEs to effectively combine the advantages of polymer and ceramics [36]. Hou et al. designed a three-layer sandwich electrolyte. The middle layer was “polymer-in-ceramic” one that could inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites, while both external sides of the "ceramic-in-polymer" layers owned reasonable interface compatibility and reduced interface resistance [37]. Recently, an asymmetric polymer electrolyte was constructed by modifying the lithium anode surface of the MOF layer. The dense MOF layer not only regulate the transport of lithium ions, but also exhibit robust mechanical properties that can retard the growth of lithium dendrites [38]. This electrolyte is composed of a tightly packed ceramic particle-based layer and a polymer-based layer. The contact between the ceramic particle-based layer and lithium anode can effectively depress the lithium dendrite growth and assure the uniform transmission of lithium ions. The contact between the polymer-based layer and cathode can effectively diminish the interface impedance [39,40]. However, LLZTO particles have limited wettability with lithium metal, such a poor contact will increase local current density and form the local lithium dendrites at the interface [23,41–43]. By deposing Li3PO4 on the atomic layer of LLZTO surface, an artificial SEI layer with moderate ionic conduct and electronic insulation was formed. This layer could promote the uniform deposition and compatibility of lithium metal anode [44]. Therefore, the special structural design of CPEs that can not only suppress the lithium dendrites growth but also improve the lithium-ion transmission of SSLMBs will be of great significance.

Here, a simple and scalable approach was developed for the fabrication of an asymmetric CPE, which incorporates a ceramic-rich layer on the anode side and a polymer-rich layer on the cathode side through selective adsorption of a glass fiber separator. Local conjugate structure chains formed by ethers compounds in SSEs could favor the transfer of Li-plus within the SCL due to their wide electron distribution. Consequently, the conjugated polymer SSEs nano-wrapped around the surface of ceramic oxide particles construct a Li+ conduction channel via in-situ polymerization. Meanwhile, this new lithium transport route was analyzed by Li solid NMR spectra and in-situ TEM. Moreover, the softened polymer-rich layer can effectively wet the cathode, imparting an excellent interfacial stability. The ceramic particles on the anode side can inhibit effectively the growth of dendrites and facilitate lithium-ion transport.

The asymmetric CPE was fabricated via an in-situ thermal initiation polymerization process. The nano-LLZTO powder, monomers TPGDA (tripropylene glycol diacrylate) and VEImNTF2 (1-vinyl-3-ethylimidazolium bis(trifluoroethylimidazolium sulfonyl)imide), and AIBN (azodiisobutyronitrile) were added to a liquid electrolyte (LE), and the mixture was stirred vigorously for 1 h to form a homogeneous solution. These mixtures were injected rapidly into the assembled 2025-coin type cells until the glass fibers (GF) were completely infiltrated. The cells were then maintained at 50 °C for 5 h to ensure the complete polymerization of TPGDA and VEImNTF2 (see the details in support information). Furthermore, an asymmetric CPE was designed by applying GF and LLZTO on Li-metal batteries, as illustrated in Fig. 1a. GF provided a 3D fiber network with liquid precursors and selective adsorption of LLZTO. The LLZTO coated SSEs (LLZTO@SSEs) could effectively suppress lithium dendrites on the anode and pave some new pathways for Li+ conduction between SSEs and ceramic oxide.

The space charge layer (SCL) is one of the origins for the reduced transport of lithium ions at the solid electrode/electrolyte interface [45]. SCLs, which can act as p-n junctions in semiconductors, were generally formed at the LLZTO/SSEs interface due to the mismatch of electronic band edges between the two materials [46,47]. In SCLs, the charges are no longer neutral and the separation of charges will create an internal electric field at the boundary. The formation of SCLs that might be detrimental to interfacial ion transfer according to Cheng’s study [48]. However, once a localized conjugate structure was presented on the polymer side of the SCL, lithium ions tend to be resided in a charge-rich SCL than in a charge-deficient SCL, and the charge compensation effect was weakened, as the latter may lead to strengthened electrostatic interactions [41]. Therefore, stronger electronic transfer on the LLZTO/SSEs interface can facilitate interface lithium-ion exchange, consistent with the solid-state NMR data. Meanwhile, local conjugated structure chains formed by TPGDA monomers in SSEs could promote the transfer of rich charge within the SCL. Such a behavior is possibly due to their broad electron distribution. Furthermore, the interactions can be calculated using an interfacial model. Fig. S1b depicts the complex structure of the LLZTO-polymer interface. The LLZTO/SSEs interaction was calculated to be −0.28 eV. The calculated charge difference distribution (CDD) demonstrates the apparent conjugate structure between LLZTO and SSEs, which also reveals stronger electron transfer at the LLZTO/SSEs interface. The Li salt in the polymer phase usually interacts with the residual solvent molecules via ion−dipole force or with monomers TPGDA by coupling with the CO/CO. Consequently, the altered lithium-ion transport mechanism will greatly increase the rate of ion migration.

Li-ion transport mechanism of solid-state electrolytes containing ceramic particles was studied by using a high-resolution solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) technique [49,50]. The high-resolution 7Li NMR spectra of LLZTO@SSEs composites are shown in Fig. 1c. The 7Li NMR spectra of pristine LLZTO and SSEs are used as references. A single 7Li resonance at 1.24 ppm was observed for LiPF6 within the SSEs, and the one positioned at 2.65 ppm should stem from Li in pristine cubic-LLZTO. The 7Li spectrum of the LLZTO@SSEs composite exhibits, in addition to the 1.24 ppm and 2.65 ppm peaks, a third component at around − 2.60 ppm, which may be assigned to Li at the LLZTO and SSEs interface [51,52]. Meanwhile, the interface peak position at − 0.57 ppm is also clearly observed in 6Li NMR spectra in Fig. S1 . Such characteristics indicate that LLZTO@SSEs particles can provide new routes for the effective conduction of Li ions.

The photos of liquid precursor of CPE–0% LLZTO and CPE–10% LLZTO before and after polymerization can be confirmed by visual observation in Fig. S2. X-ray computed tomography characterization ( Fig. 2a) obviously suggest that an asymmetrical CPE–10% LLZTO was constructed successfully via the selective adsorption of GF separator due to an interception affect. This process led to the formation of a ceramic-rich layer on the anode side and a polymer-rich layer on the cathode side. Meanwhile, the surface feature of used CPE–10% LLZTO membranes, from the disassembled batteries with opposite sides, also confirms the asymmetrical structure. As presented in Fig. 2b, after the polymerization of the precursors, the bare GF exhibited a loose surface with many voids between the fibers that have been filled with the polymer electrolyte. Previous report reveals that the liquid precursors could be easily permeated into the electrodes on account of their good fluidity and wettability, thus establishing a stable electrolyte-electrode interface and reduced interface impedance [53]. The other side attached to lithium anode (Fig. 2c) with high content LLZTO particles exhibites enhanced mechanical strength due to the selective adsorption of GF. The thickness of CPEs inside the cell after the in-situ polymerization is about 485 µm and GF is about 378 µm (Fig. S3a-b).

TEM investigation was conducted to assess the microstructure of LLZTO@SSEs. As displayed in Fig. 2d-e, LLZTO particles with an average size of less than 100 nm were surrounded and connected by a non-uniform polymer coating formed on the particle surface. The highly homogeneous distribution of different elements, as illustrated in EDS mapping (Fig. 2f), indicating that SSEs with C, O, N and F elements are coated onto LLZTO. More importantly, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique (Fig. 2g) was used to study the chemical environment of LLZTO@SSEs. In the C 1 s spectrum, the typical peaks of the C-F bond at 292.5 eV and CO bond at 288.7 eV were clearly detected. They should origin from the trifluoromethyl group and carbonyl groups, respectively [26,54]. In the N 1 s and F 1 s spectra, the signal of imidazole-N and F-P are positioned at 399.1 eV and 686.2 eV, respectively, corresponding to VEImNTF2 and LiPF6. Therefore, this asymmetric CPE exhibits exceptional interfacial contact with the electrodes in lithium batteries.

The appropriate ratio of monomer TPGDA and VEImNTF2 was firstly assessed. As illustrated in Fig. S4a, ionic conductivity was tested with the same LE precursor content at room temperature (RT). The SPE-4 shows a value of 0.11 mS cm−1, it is much higher than that of the others. Fig. S4b shows the ionic conductivities of SPEs with different contents of LE at RT. The ionic conductivity of SPE-8 (0.15 mS cm−1) is slightly higher than that of SPE-7 (0.11 mS cm−1). However, for safety reasons, the LE content should be as low as possible while ensuring electrical conductivity. Therefore, 60 wt% LE is considered as an ideal value. Then, various contents of LLZTO were added into above SPEs. Fig. 3a and Fig. S5 show the dependence of ionic conductivity on temperature ranging from −20 to 75 °C. The ionic conductivities of CPE–10% LLZTO is 0.69 mS cm−1 at 25 °C and 0.13 mS cm−1 at 0 °C. The ionic conductivity rose firstly and then began to drop with the increase of ceramic oxide. The interface wettability was diminished due to the agglomeration of LLZTO particles at high concentrations (> 10 wt%), resulting into lowered conductivity.

Shown in Fig. 3b are the FTIR spectra of solid-state electrolytes. The characteristic transmittance peaks at 1624 cm−1 and 1720 cm−1 can be assigned to the CC and CO, respectively [55,56]. Interestingly, the CC in the VEImNTF2 exhibited a blue shift phenomenon, it was due to the formation of a large conjugate structure via imidazole and CC bond. Such structures can effectively reduce the system energy. The disappearance of CC implies the successful formation of SPEs. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) profile (Fig. 3c) suggests that CPE–10% LLZTO delivered a wide electrochemical stability window up to 4.6 V compared to CPE–0% LLZTO (about 3.8 V) at RT by Li/CPE/SS cells. This result reconfirms the superior anti-oxidation stability for CPE–10% LLZTO. It can satisfy well most of the available voltage requirements. As is well known, the Li-ion transference number (
t
Li
+
) play a vital role in the ionic conductivity of CPEs. Fig. S6 and Fig. 3d illustrate that the employment of LLZTO increased the
t
Li
+
from 0.11 to 0.52 at RT. As for CPE-10% LLZTO, With the presence of LLZTO, the formation of LLZTO@SSEs structure could provide high-speed transmission channels and promote lithium-ion transmission. It can also be confirmed by the lowered resistance of the LLZTO at CPE-10%. The mechanical properties of CPE–10% LLZTO were further explored by an atomic force microscope (AFM) test (diagram in Fig. S7a). As plotted in force-distance curves (Fig. 3e and Fig. S7b), the Young's modulus of CPE–10% LLZTO (60.1 MPa) is higher than that of CPE–0% LLZTO (26.4 MPa). This result suggests that CPE–10% LLZTO films with higher mechanical strength are beneficial for the inhibition of lithium dendrites. Overall, as depicted in Fig. 3f. The above analysis makes the design of CPE-10% LLZTO with great potential for application in SSLMBs.

To gain more insights into the electrochemical stability of CPE films to lithium metal, constant current discharge/charge voltage distributions were used to investigate the lithium plating/ stripping behavior and cycling stability in symmetric Li/Li cells. To evaluate the critical current density of CPE doped with 10% LLZTO@SSEs, a rate performance test was performed on Li/Li symmetric cells at varied current densities ranging from 0.05 to 2.6 mA cm−2. The CPE-10%LLZTO membrane showed a critical current density up to 2.4 mA cm−2 within a stripping/plating period of 5 min [57] as displayed in Fig. 4a. Furthermore, Li=CPE-10%LLZTO=Li batteries showed a stable and low potential for over 1500 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm–2, and 600 h at 0.2 mA cm–2 (Fig. 4b and Fig. S8). The overpotential (not more than 100 mV) rose gradually, this behavior was caused by ohmic polarization and concentration polarization, respectively [24]. The lithium symmetrical batteries of CPE-0%LLZTO became unstable after 140 h at 0.1 mA cm−2. It further confirms that CPE-10%LLZTO films inhibited the growth of lithium dendrites and reduced the resistance of the interface.

The morphology of lithium disc after cycled for 100 numbers at 0.2 mA cm−2 was also investigated by SEM. Lithium foil disassembled from a Li/CPE-10%LLZTO/Li cell (Fig. 4d-e) exhibits a homogeneous surface and could maintain robust contact with the composite electrolyte. No lithium dendrite was observed, indicating homogeneous plating/stripping of lithium metal at the CPE-10%LLZTO interface. In contrast, numerous lithium dendrites were formed after prolonged cycling in CPE-0% LLZTO. As presented in Fig. S9 , the impedance of Li| CPE-10% LLZTO |Li is lower than that of CPE-0% LLZTO before cycles, implying a lower polarization voltage. Fig. 4c shows that the lithium metal became porous and exhibited a mossy feature with a loose structure. This new and universal strategy may pave a way to promote the rapid migration of lithium-ion through the electrolyte and uniform deposition on the lithium metal surface.

To understand the underlying mechanism of the superior performance of the Li/CPE-10% LLZTO/Li interface in Li/Li symmetric cells, systematical characterizations were performed. The XPS technique was used to evaluate the chemical environment of the Li/CPE interface that has been cycled for 100 numbers. In combination with C 1 s spectrum ( Fig. 5a), the SEI layer with cycled Li surface of CPE–10% LLZTO contains few Li2CO3 compounds, which are not beneficial to the formation of a strong and dense SEI film. As depicted in the P 2p spectra, both the peaks at 134.0 eV and 136.8 eV correspond to LixPOyFz and LixPFy from the decomposition of LiPF6, respectively [58]. Apparently, the signal of LixPOyFz is barely visible in CPE-10% LLZTO, indicating that decomposition is severe in the CPE-0% LLZTO electrolyte and that small amounts of water can be effectively absorbed using LLZTO as an electrolyte additive. Further, hydrolysis of PF6 - resulted in the formation of HF and low fluorine substances (LixPOyFz and LiF). These compounds give rise to large interfacial impedances and the inhomogeneous formation of SEI. Meanwhile, the F 1 s spectrum also proved this hypothesis. The peak at 684.8 eV derived from LiF components was weaker on the lithium anode cycled with CPE-0%LLZTO electrolyte than that of 10 wt% LLZTO@SSEs-containing electrolyte. Compared with CPE-10%LLZTO, the bonding energy of LixPOyFz and LixPFy and LiF decreased in CPE-0%LLZTO. This is due to the fact that these compounds can form stable F(O)---H-F hydrogen bonds with HF (H2O) in the presence of small amounts of water in the electrolyte [59].

To investigate the origin of excellent circulation performance and ion conductivity of CPE-10% LLZTO, in-situ TEM observation was carried out on charge and discharge process to explore the evolution of its microstructure (Fig. 5b). One LLZTO@SSEs sphere was attached to a gold wire as an electrode, while a tungsten wire with a piece of lithium metal was used as the counter electrode [60,61]. Fig. 5c shows an in-situ TEM image of the first lithium-ion insertion. SSEs display an expansion after lithiation. The in-situ TEM measurement suggests that the SSEs exhibit good structural stability during lithiation, resulting into superior cycling performance in SSLMBs [62]. In addition, the SSEs can limit the direct contact between the LLZTO and the lithium cathode, which therefore will effectively reduce the interfacial impedance. Such a configuration can provide the basis for a new lithium-ion channel between the SSEs and the ceramic oxide.

The applicable temperature range is vital for the next generation energy storage devices. To further evaluate the application potential of CPE-10% LLZTO, the assembled SSLMBs were tested at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6a, the cell containing CPE-10% LLZTO electrolyte exhibited excellent rate and cycling performances. Simultaneously, the typical charge-discharge profiles of Li/LFP batteries were collected. As shown in Fig. S10 , it delivered stable discharge capacities of 153.1, 149.3, 142.6 and 129.5 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C. In addition, the discharge capacity of the cell with CPE-10% LLZTO almost returned to its original value once the current was rebacked to 0.5 C and maintained for a long time due to the SEI formed during cycling remaining stable and its high ionic conductivity (0.69 mS cm-1). On the contrary, batteries using CPE-0% LLZTO electrolytes could not maintain stable charge and discharge and display at identical C-rate, due to the presence of unstable Coulombic efficiency and excessive side reactions. In addition, the EIS measurement further confirmed that the interface between the electrode and the solid electrolyte was ultra-stable during long-term cycling (Fig. S11) [63]. Fig. 6b shows the charge/discharge voltage profiles at 0.5 C at various temperatures, delivering specific capacities of 122.5, 148.7, 140.8, and 136.1 mA h g−1 at 0, 25, 60, and 70 °C. Once the temperature was elevated to 60 °C, the discharge capacity dropped significantly. It was probably due to the decomposition of LiPF6 and the drastic side effects of electrolyte at high temperature. Meanwhile, the long-term cycling of the CPE-10% LLZTO cell at 60 °C and 70 °C are shown in Fig. S12.

As shown in Fig. 6c, the optimized cell also exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 126.5 m Ah g−1 at a rate of 0.5 C even at 0 °C due to its high ionic conductivity (0.13 mS cm−1). Moreover, CPE-10% LLZTO based cell delivered a super-stable cycle performance with a capacity retention of around 88.3% after 600 cycles and average Coulombic efficiency of about 100%. Interestingly, the CPE-10% LLZTO exhibited more excellent performances at 0 °C. It may be due to the fact that rare side effects took place at low temperature. As plotted in Fig. 6d, the Li/CPE-10% LLZTO/LFP cell maintained stable cycling at low temperatures (−20 °C and −10 °C) with an average Coulomb efficiency of 99.8%. These results can be attributed to the absence of undesirable side reactions at the CPE-10% LLZTO-electrode interface and the ability to maintain the fast lithium-ion transport of the cell even at low temperatures. Thus, the assembled Li/CPE-10% LLZTO/LFP full cell exhibited exceptional cycling performance and electrochemical stability over a wide temperature range (−20 to 70 °C). Further studies on the properties of CPE over a wide temperature range would be of great interest.

As investigated by TEM images (Fig. 6e-f), thick and nonuniform deposited layer (about 39.5 nm) was formed on the surface of the LFP cathode using CPE-0% LLZTO, implying that this electrolyte underwent severe decomposition and irregular deposition. In contrast, after cycling with the CPE-10% LLZTO electrolyte, the main active material particles were protected by an amorphous CEI layer (about 15.0 nm). By blocking the direct attack of the electrolyte to the cathode, it would effectively inhibit further decomposition of the electrolyte. The pouch cell (Fig. 6g) could light up a LED device, demonstrating the high safety of the Li/CPE-10% LLZTO/LFP pouch cell. These CPEs have the potential to be used in the future for the manufacture of commercially available flexible devices with high safety and stability over a wide temperature range.

In summary, an asymmetric bilayer solid-stated electrolyte was synthesized via a simple selective adsorption and in-situ thermal polymerization process. The locally conjugated structural chains formed by the ethers compounds in the SSEs can facilitate the transfer of lithium ions in the space charge layer due to their broad electron distribution. Consequently, the conjugated polymer solid electrolyte wrapped on the surface of ceramic oxide particles creates new Li+ conduction channels during in situ polymerization. Furthermore, CPE-10% LLZTO possesses high ionic conductivity of 0.69 mS cm−1 at 25 °C and 0.13 mS cm−1 at 0 °C. Meanwhile, Li-metal batteries using this CPE exhibit excellent cycling stability from −20 – 70 °C and ultra-long cycle performance (> 600 cycles) at 0.5 C under 0 °C, suggesting the feasibility of asymmetric bilayer for CPE based SSLMBs. In-depth understanding the mechanisms of lithium-ion conduction in ceramic-polymer composite electrolytes, will be helpful for the rational design of asymmetric bilayer solid electrolytes and electrode/electrolyte interfaces for rechargeable wide-temperature lithium metal batteries.

Jin Li: Methodology, Software, Validation, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft, Investigation, Writing – review & editing, Data curation. Yingjun Cai: Visualization, Formal analysis. Yingyue Cui: Visualization, Formal analysis. Hui Wu: measurement, Formal analysis. Yijun Yang: measurement, Formal analysis. Haoran Da: Software, Formal analysis. Haitao Zhang: Resources, Visualization, Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition. Suojiang Zhang: Resources, Supervision.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Jin Li received his B.S. degree in chemical engineering and technology from Qufu Normal University in 2018. He is currently pursuing his Ph.D. degree at Institute of process engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences under the supervision of Prof. Suojiang Zhang and Haitao Zhang. His research focuses on the Design and performance study of solid-state electrolytes based on interface regulation.

Dr Yingjun Cai is an associate professor in Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese academy of Sciences, received her Ph.D Degree from the department of chemical and biochemical engineering at Technical University of Denmark. Her main research interests include lithium batteries and Zinc air batteries devices, storage electrode materials, liquid and solid electrolytes, and synthesis of ionic liquids for electrochemistry.

Yingyue Cui obtained her M.S. degree from Hebei university of technology in 2020. Then she started to pursue her Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Suojiang Zhang and Haitao Zhang at Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her research is focused on the design and fabrication of novel carbonbased materials for highenergy-density lithium-sulfur batteries.

Hui Wu obtained her M.S. degree in Physical Chemistry from Taiyuan University of Technology. She joined institute of process engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2007. Her research interests mainly focus on physical properties and adsorption properties of ionic liquids, synthesis, and characterization of C1 chemical catalytic materials, nanomaterial chemistry, etc.

Haoran Da received his M.S. degree in China university of petroleum. Currently, he is pursuing his PhD degree in Institute of Process Engineering, university of Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests are mainly focuses on spent graphite anodes recovery.

Dr Yijun Yang received his Ph.D. degree in Physical Chemistry from the Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ICCAS). He joined School of Science, Beijing Jiaotong University in 2016. His research interests mainly focus on the controlled synthesis and exploration of fundamental properties of functional nanomaterials, as well as their applications in energy storage and catalysis.

Haitao Zhang earned his Ph.D. degree from the University of Sciences and Technology of China in 2006. After that, he conducted his postdoctoral research in National University of Singapore and National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS, Japan). Since 2012 he has been assigned as a professor in the Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His current research interests focus on the new energy materials, energy storage techniques, and spent battery recyclization. He has authored or co-authored more than 90 papers in peer reviewed SCI journals, such as Adv. Mater., Phys. Rev. Lett., Energy Storage Mater, Adv. Funct. Materal, et al.

Prof. Suojiang Zhang is currently Director General of the Institute of Process Engineering (IPE), CAS, Dean of College of Chemical Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences (UCAS), and a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC). He was elected as a Member of CAS in 2015. He is dedicated to promoting innovation and application of Ionic Liquids (ILs) in green process engineering and has achieved groundbreaking results. He has also won several academic awards, such as the Second-Class Prize of National Natural Science Award, the Hou Debang Chemical Science and Technology Outstanding Achievement Award, and the Ho Leung Ho Lee Foundation Science and Technology Progress Awards.
